gorr 0.2.3.9000

    • Executing a Basic GOR Query
  • Changelog

    Installation

    See this blog: https://nextcode.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/CDG/blog/2018/07/11/765198379/Try+out+GOR+in+R+yourself

    In the future we could publish our package so that you can install the released version of gorr from CRAN with:

    install.packages("gorr")

    Example

    In this example, we’re going to run a simple remote gor query using the gorr package.

    Load packages

    First load the gorr package, the tidyverse package is recommended in general, but not required for this example

    library(gorr)
library(tidyverse)

    Connecting to the direct query service

    First we’ll need to establish a connection to our direct query API. To do that we’ll need to call gor_connect and provide it with the relevant parameters pointing to the direct-query-service, i.e. api_key and project. You get the API Key from the /api-key-service/token endpoint on your CSA instance, and you can find a list of projects available to you in CSA as well, remember to use the internal project name. Once you have those two things, you have everything you need to make a connection object:

    api_key <- "eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiJ9.eyJqdGkiOiJjNWU4MWFiNC1hZTk4LTQxYmItOTNlMi0xMDM5NTE0MGJjZDMiLCJleHAiOjAsIm5iZiI6MCwiaWF0IjoxNTMwODk2ODk0LCJpc3MiOiJodHRwczovL3BsYXRmb3JtLnd1eGluZXh0Y29kZWRldi5jb20vYXV0aC9yZWFsbXMvd3V4aW5leHRjb2RlLmNvbSIsImF1ZCI6ImFwaS1rZXktY2xpZW50Iiwic3ViIjoiOTNmNTMyYjQtODFlOC00YmJkLTk3NTctN2FlOWU2ZmMzZmI1IiwidHlwIjoiT2ZmbGluZSIsImF6cCI6ImFwaS1rZXktY2xpZW50Iiwibm9uY2UiOiIzZjA4ZmM1YS03OWYzLTQzODItOThiZi1hY2ZlMjdhZmI1YWEiLCJzZXNzaW9uX3N0YXRlIjoiZTE0MDZiZjAtN2FlZC00NjkyLTljZmMtZjhmYTU2ZjZlZDUyIiwiY2xpZW50X3Nlc3Npb24iOiJmZGQ0ODhkYy0zYWQ5LTQ5NmQtYWI3NC0xMmJkMDk3ZTFlMTciLCJyZWFsbV9hY2Nlc3MiOnsicm9sZXMiOlsib2ZmbGluZV9hY2Nlc3MiLCJ1bWFfYXV0aG9yaXphdGlvbiJdfSwicmVzb3VyY2VfYWNjZXNzIjp7ImFwaS1rZXktY2xpZW50Ijp7InJvbGVzIjpbIm9mZmxpbmVfYWNjZXNzIiwidW1hX3Byb3RlY3Rpb24iXX0sImFjY291bnQiOnsicm9sZXMiOlsibWFuYWdlLWFjY291bnQiLCJ2aWV3LXByb2ZpbGUiXX19fQ.fu5A-x6dkcg_mXoiAljsmZhFBklFa0KFAGVfnV2IITJ4kiQNE2NHmx-PU6O_wCanI2Y-oj0n6jtU0KQylODXKZrhiAPEvcZRLCsDDb-ZC3zHDekYm51MJkLN9vZ7n4fG7xH9AuoSS9L0-gyg5JBuLP-IdHkaovGqfjxmVZyObHSuPDYpr7IP-ZxzpCrnAsLS3Hjhv4WdAEnexB7UzMNNy5WD-g5H3izdcpy1KCOM1nCdkfYnvquXLYoo9cgIXMJ_EvVkk8Rlk95jEzacnUDo9pds1OTAzXnkpeDP8fEIwpw7O7Bw44GODf2FtvMNdvOGnFAsa7_JANT0CD5YFHCOpw"
conn <- gor_connect(api_key, project = "test_proj")

    If everything goes as planned, we’ll have a conn object to pass into the gor_query function to finally run a query:

    result <- gor_query("gor #dbsnp# | top 100", conn)

    The results come back as an R data.frame:

    print(result)

    It should also be noted that larger gor queries can be constructed inside a string block and piped directly into the gor_query function:

    chr21_results <- "
  gor -p chr21 #dbsnp# 
    | where len(reference)=1 and len(allele)=1
    | calc snptype reference+'/'+allele 
    | hide rsIDs
    | top 100" %>%
    gor_query(conn)
    print(chr21_results)
